messages.subject: Re:How to define the samurai?
messages.msgSnippet: Ojayo! Need some help from your expertise... Reading trough lines on the internet, I´ve been trying to understand the difference between the samurai and any
messages.messageBody:
Ojayo!
Need some help from your expertise...

Reading trough lines on the internet, I�ve been trying
to understand the difference between "the samurai" and
any other knight...I was reading about the seven
principles codified by Yamagei Yoko and I�ve found
that If try I can definetely follow all of them from a
very humanistic perception and, I really now, that
won�t make of me a samurai...I wish it with all my
heart but I know it is quite different to will than to
be...

Then my question: How can I define the samurai beyond
these principles when these are the basis for them???

Anyone can suggest me any book to move forward on this
issues???

Sincerely

Ivo.

> Subject: Re: History of Samurai

> On May 8, 2004, at 8:12 AM, whats_there_to_fear
> wrote:
>
> > I would also like to
> > read about some sword makers. However,
>
> Ian-
> A very good book for introduction to the Japanese
> sword, it's history,
> and some famous smiths is "The Japanese Sword" by
> Sato Kanzan (trans.
> Joe Earle) from Kodansha. Afu Research has
> translated Fujishiros'
> Dictionary of swordsmiths", a specialists book
> really and not cheap but
> there are many good stories therein. Of course the
> very best books
> relating "tales of swordsmiths" are by Fukunaga
> Suiken and are to date
> unfortunately only in Japanese.
>
> Tom "happy to talk swords anytime" Helm
>
> http://www.afuresearch.com/
>
>
>
>
